introduction.p: Earlier we considered systems of quadratic equations involving two parabolas. Those systems can have one, two, or no solutions, depending on the graphs of the two equations. Systems involving other conics may have up to four solutions.

statement.p: Find the intersection points of the graphs of \begin{aligned}[t] x^2+y^2\amp = 5\\ xy \amp = 2\\ \end{aligned}

solution.p: We will use substitution to solve the system. First we solve the "easier" of the two equations (the second equation) for y to obtain y=\dfrac{2}{x} We substitute \alert{\dfrac{2}{x}} for y in the first equation to find x^2 + (\alert{\dfrac{2}{x}})^2 = 5 ~~~~\text{or} ~~~~~ x^2 + \dfrac{4}{x^2}=5 This equation has only one variable, x, and we solve it by first clearing fractions. We multiply both sides by x^2, and then subtract 5x^2 to obtain x^4-5x^2+4=0 Then we factor the left side to get (x^2-1)(x^2-4)=0 and apply the zero-factor principle to find x^2-1 = 0 ~~~~ \text{or} ~~~~ x^2-4=0 We solve each of these equations to find x=1,~~ x=-1, ~~ x=2, ~~ \text{or} ~~ x=-2 Finally, we substitute each of these values into y=\dfrac{2}{x} to find the y-components of each solution. The intersection points of the two graphs are (1,2),~ (-1,-2), ~ (2,1) and (-2,-1). The graph of the system is shown below.

subsection.title: Solving Systems by Elimination
subsection.p: In Example 1 we used substitution to solve the system. If both equations are of the form ax^2+by^2=c elimination of variables is more efficient.

statement.p: Find the solutions to the following system of the equations. \begin{aligned}[t] x^2-2y^2\amp = 1\\ \dfrac{x^2}{15}+\dfrac{y^2}{10} \amp = 1\\ \end{aligned} Verify the solutions on a graph.

solution.p: We multiply the first equation by 3 and the second by 60 to obtain the new system \begin{aligned}[t] 3x^2-6y^2\amp = 3\\ 4x^2+6y^2 \amp = 60\\ \end{aligned} Adding these two equations, we have \begin{aligned}[t] 7x^2\amp = 63\\ x^2 \amp = 9\\ x \amp = \pm 3\\ \end{aligned} We substitute these values for into any of the equations involving y and solve, to find the solutions (3,2), ~ (3,-2),~ (-3,2) and (-3,-2).

The two original equations describe a hyperbola and an ellipse. We can obtain graphs on a graphing utility by solving each equation for y to get \begin{aligned}[t] y\amp = \pm\sqrt{\dfrac{x^2-1}{2}}\\ y \amp = \pm\sqrt{10(1-\dfrac{x^2}{15}}\\ \end{aligned} We enter these equations to obtain the graph shown below. The solutions of the system are the intersection points of the graphs.

statement.p: Find the intersection points of the graphs of \begin{aligned}[t] x^2-y^2\amp = 5\\ x^2 + y^2 \amp = 13\\ \end{aligned}

subsection.p: For some quadratic systems, we can use a combination of elimination of variables and substitution.

statement.p: Find the intersection of the circles given by the equations. \begin{aligned}[t] x^2 - 4x + y^2 + 2y\amp = 20\\ x^2 - 12x + y^2 + 10y \amp = -12\\ \end{aligned}

solution.p:
We subtract the second equation from the first to obtain 8x-8y=32 Solving for x we have x=y+4 We substitute \alert{y+4} for x into either of the original equations. We'll use the first equation. \begin{aligned}[t] (\alert{y+4})^2 - 4(\alert{y+4}) + y^2 + 2y\amp = 20\\ (y^2+8y+16)- 4y-16 +y^2 + 2y \amp = 20\\ 2y^2+6y-20 \amp = 0\\ y^2+3y-10 \amp = 0\\ (y+5)(y-2) \amp = 0\\ \end{aligned}
Thus y=-5 or y=2. From our first new equation we find that when y=-5,~ x=-1, and when y=2,~ x=6. Thus the two circles intersect at (-1,-5) and (6,2), as shown below.
